LEAD: IT'S tough to be a monument in New York City.
IT'S tough to be a monument in New York City.
Acid rain and toxic fumes from motor vehicles and factories gnaw at bronze and pepper sleek marble into a spongy-looking mass. Vandals with paint cans move in on the remains.
In March 1987 the Municipal Art Society, in cooperation with the city's Art Commission and Parks and Recreation Department, suggested that the most needy monuments be put up for public adoption.
Twenty were chosen, and private donors were invited to repair and maintain them. Within eight months, 13 monuments had been adopted.
Since then three more have been adopted, and volunteers are caring for two others that were not part of the original 20, reports Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern.

That leaves four orphans: the Heinrich Heine Fountain in the Bronx; the Soldiers and Sailors Monument in Hillside, Queens; the William Jenkins Worth Monument in Manhattan, and the Clarence T. Barrett Memorial on Staten Island.

It will take big hearts and big pocketbooks to adopt the Heine and Worth monuments - $275,000 and $150,000, respectively, just for refurbishing. The estimate for the Queens monument is $17,000, and for the one on Staten Island, $5,850.
Inspired by the city's adoption program, Chicago, Boston and San Francisco, have started similar efforts, says Paul Gunther, director of development for the art society.
